Informal and Colloquial Expressions.desc: Because academic writing is more formal than other kinds of writing, some words or expressions that may be acceptable in emails, blog posts, or text messages are too informal for academic contexts and may come across as unsophisticated. Here are some informal and colloquial words to avoid in academic writing.

America.suggestion: the United States, the US, the USA
America.example: The study focused on <America> -> <the United States>.

big.example: A <big> -> <significant> amount of evidence supports this theory.

humongous.example: A <humongous> -> <significant> amount of evidence supports this theory.

huge.example: A <huge> -> <significant> amount of evidence supports this theory.

has got.example: The senator said that the government <has got> -> <must> act.

get.example: The writer <get> -> <received> a prize for her work.

got.example: The writer <got> -> <received> a prize for her work.

give.example: Table 5.2 <give> -> <provides> evidence to support this conclusion.

good.suggestion: optimal, strong, prime (or replace with a more descriptive adjective)

kind of.suggestion: somewhat, to some degree, in the category of

sort of.suggestion: somewhat, to some degree, in the category of

till.example: The study will run from March <till> -> <until> May.

show.example: The interviews <showed> -> <revealed> a shared concern over safety.

Vague Writing.desc: Academic writing should be as precise as possible. Unambiguous language strengthens papers, while vague wording leaves too much to a reader’s interpretation. Whenever possible, prefer exact values—percentages, measurements, statistics—to broader terms. Here are some imprecise words to avoid in academic writing.

a bit.example: The experiment required <a bit> -> <10 mg> of catalyst.

a couple of.suggestion: Specify the exact amount or replace with many, several, a number of.
a couple of.example: <A couple of> -> <A total of 30> students were surveyed.

some.suggestion: Specify the exact amount or replace with many, several, a number of.

a lot of.suggestion: Specify the exact amount or replace with many, several, a great number of, significant, or numerous.
a lot of.example: The announcement received <a lot of> -> <significant> attention.

lots of.suggestion: Specify the exact amount or replace with many, several, a great number of, significant, or numerous.

a ton.suggestion: Specify the exact amount or replace with many, several, a great number of, a substantial amount of, or significant.
a ton.example: The government spent <a ton> -> <$5 million> on the project.

and so on.suggestion: Either finish the thought, eliminate the phrase, or replace with a more specific phrase like including other factors or additionally.
and so on.example: Civil engineers must consider load, terrain, weather <and so on> -> <many other factors> when designing a bridge.

anything.example: The writer could be referencing <anything> -> <three separate themes: the narrator’s grief, the uneasy political situation, or death in general.>

something.example: The writer could be referencing <something> -> <three separate themes: the narrator’s grief, the uneasy political situation, or death in general.>

most.suggestion: Specify the amount or replace with many or the majority of.

stuff.suggestion: Specify the item(s), or replace with object, sample, point, or finding.

thing.suggestion: Specify the item(s), or replace with object, sample, point, or finding.

Exaggerations.desc:
Academic writing should allow for reasonable doubt. While academic writers can be confident, they must acknowledge that their ideas and theories may be disproven. Avoid language that suggests absolute authority or knowledge.

Superlatives, such as largest and best, should be used only if they refer to provable facts (for example, describing a company as the largest in Europe) or if the writer is quoting another source (for example, saying that Rolling Stone ranked a certain recording as the best single of 2018).

always.suggestion: Specify the amount or replace with the word frequently.
always.example: <The results were always the same.> ->The results were <the same over 120 iterations>.

definitely.suggestion: Eliminate or replace with greatly, likely, significantly, or strongly.
definitely.example: The findings <absolutely> -> <significantly> provide significant support for the proposed legislation.

absolutely.suggestion: Eliminate or replace with greatly, likely, significantly, or strongly.
absolutely.example: The findings <absolutely> -> <significantly> provide significant support for the proposed legislation.

every.suggestion: Specify the amount or add a phrase to convey reasonable doubt, such as almost, essentially, or recorded.
every.example: <Every> -> <Every recorded> species of this genus is found in the Brazilian Amazon.

never.suggestion: Specify the amount or replace with the word rarely.
never.example: <Surveyed respondents never chose the fourth option.> -> <None of the 30 surveyed respondents chose the fourth option.>

none.suggestion: Specify the amount or add a phrase to convey reasonable doubt, such as almost, essentially, or recorded.
none.example: <None of the respondents answered positively.> -> <No respondents answered positively.>

Subjectivity.desc: In academic writing, arguments must be supported by evidence. Avoid words that imply conclusions based on the writer’s personal opinions; use objective language to support the main argument. Here are some subjective words to avoid in academic writing.

beautiful.suggestion: Specify the quality as objectively as possible.

wonderful.suggestion: Specify the quality as objectively as possible.
wonderful.example: The composition was <wonderful> -> <full of clashing movements>.

awful.suggestion: Specify the quality as objectively as possible.
awful.example: The composition was <awful> -> <full of clashing movements>.

ugly.suggestion: Specify the quality as objectively as possible.
ugly.example: The composition was <ugly> -> <full of clashing movements>.

hideous.suggestion: Specify the quality as objectively as possible.
hideous.example: The composition was <hideous> -> <full of clashing movements>.

better.suggestion: Replace with a more objective word or phrase.
better.example: The candidate had a <better> -> <more comprehensive> plan to address climate change than his opponent.

clearly.suggestion: Eliminate or replace with a more objective word.
clearly.example: <clearly> -> The programmer wrote the application in Java.

naturally.suggestion: Eliminate or replace with a more objective word.
naturally.example: <naturally> -> The programmer wrote the application in Java.

of course.suggestion: Eliminate or replace with a more objective word.
of course.example: <of course> -> After the war, economic policy changed.

obviously.suggestion: Eliminate or replace with a more objective word.
obviously.example: <obviously> -> After the war, economic policy changed.

undoubtedly.suggestion: Eliminate or replace with a more objective word.
undoubtedly.example: <undoubtedly> -> After the war, economic policy changed.

perfect.suggestion: Replace with a more specific qualifier or the words strong, key, or crucial.

ideal.suggestion: Replace with a more specific qualifier or the words strong, key, or crucial.

best.suggestion: Replace with a more specific qualifier or the words strong, key, or crucial.

should.suggestion: Explain the rationale behind the recommendation.
should.example: <should> ->could benefit greatly from studying the protest.

Clichés and Colloquialisms.desc: Clichés are overused expressions, while colloquialisms are those patterns of expression typical of informal speech. Besides making a paper appear too informal or conversational, they suggest that the writer doesn’t have a clear idea of what she’s trying to say. Replacing such phrases with more precise language will help improve the tone of your writing. Here are some clichés that are best avoided in academic writing.

a happy medium.example: The two sides reached <a happy medium> -> <a compromise>.

a stumbling block.example: The proposal encountered <a stumbling block> -> <an obstacle> when the opposing party mounted a negative press campaign.

above board.example: Unlike previous proposals, the resolution was <above board> -> <legitimate>.

at the end of the day.example: <At the end of the day> -> <Ultimately>, the new law did not impact the rural population.

when all is said and done.example: <When all is said and done> -> <Ultimately>, the new law did not impact the rural population.

get through.suggestion: Replace with a more specific verb or use endure or survive.
get through.example: The researcher had to <get through> -> <read> multiple texts.

in this day and age.suggestion: Specify the time period or use currently, presently, or today.
in this day and age.example: <In this day and age> -> <In the past decade>, social media use has become prevalent amongst millennials.

in recent years.suggestion: Specify the time period or use currently, presently, or today.
in recent years.example: <In recent years> -> <In the past decade>, social media use has become prevalent amongst millennials.

think outside the box.suggestion: Specify the idea or replace with words like creative and innovative.
think outside the box.example: The economist was known to <think outside the box> -> <propose innovative ideas>.

Fillers.desc: Some words or phrases are superfluous in academic writing, and sentences tend to be stronger when they are removed. These filler words are best avoided in academic writing.

literally.suggestion: Eliminate entirely unless you mean ‘in a literal manner.’
literally.example: The scientist had <literally> -> explored every option.

serves to.example: This quote <serves to> -> <illustrates> the author’s primary argument.

helps to.example: This quote <helps to> -> <illustrates> the author’s primary argument.

so.suggestion: Eliminate entirely or replace with a more specific word.
so.example: The poem is <so> -> <interesting> because it uses an unusual rhyme pattern.

very.suggestion: Eliminate the word or replace with important, crucial, critical, significant, key.

extremely.suggestion: Eliminate the word or replace with important, crucial, critical, significant, key.

First or second person.desc:
The first person (I/we/my/our) is not always deemed acceptable in academic papers. Given that opinions differ on this point, always consult the style guide used in your field; while you may be able to use the first person in certain sections, others may require the third person or passive language.

In contrast, the second person (you/your) is almost never used in academic writing, though it may be appropriate in creative writing or personal communication. Remember that the second person also includes commands, such as add 10 ml to the solution. In most cases, the best way to avoid the second person is to restructure the sentence.

we.suggestion: Replace with a third-person actor (the researcher, the writer) or rewrite the sentence passively.

my.suggestion: Replace with a third-person actor (the researcher, the writer) or rewrite the sentence passively.

our.suggestion: Replace with a third-person actor (the researcher, the writer) or rewrite the sentence passively.

you.suggestion: Restructure the sentence or replace with a neutral term like one or the reader.

your.suggestion: Restructure the sentence or replace with a neutral term like one or the reader.
your.example: <Your> -> <One's> assessment of the result might differ.

Gendered language.desc: Replace gendered language with gender-neutral alternatives to avoid perpetuating gender bias.

man.example: The wheel is one of <mankind> -> <humanity>'s earliest inventions.

mankind.example: The wheel is one of <mankind> -> <humanity>'s earliest inventions.

girl.example: The weather <girl> -> <reporter> warned viewers of the approach of a vicious cold snap.

lady.example: The weather <lady> -> <reporter> warned viewers of the approach of a vicious cold snap.

Miscellaneous-I.desc: Words and expressions that do not fit into other categories but are best avoided in academic writing.

that.suggestion: which or who works. Omit it.

he.suggestion: Omit it and rewrite the sentence to remove it.

she.suggestion: Omit it and rewrite the sentence to remove it.

we.suggestion: Omit it and rewrite the sentence to remove it.

they.suggestion: Omit it and rewrite the sentence to remove it.

their.suggestion: Omit it and rewrite the sentence to remove it.

them.suggestion: Omit it and rewrite the sentence to remove it.

it.suggestion: Omit it and rewrite the sentence to remove it.

this.suggestion: Delete it, or follow with a noun

think.suggestion: The research suggests, the data suggest

feel.suggestion: The research suggests, the data suggest

Miscellaneous-II.desc: Common informal, vague, or subjective words and expressions that are best avoided in academic writing.

sort of.suggestion: more precise qualifier or specify degree

kind of.suggestion: more precise qualifier or specify degree

etc..suggestion: fully enumerate items or use 'such as...'

basically.suggestion: use more precise language or omit

maybe.suggestion: use a more precise statement or indicate uncertainty with data

perhaps.suggestion: use a more precise statement or indicate uncertainty with data

somehow.example: The reaction <somehow> -> <due to unknown factors> failed.

always.suggestion: use more cautious language such as 'usually', 'typically'
always.example: The reaction <always> -> <typically> occurs at room temperature.

never.suggestion: use more cautious language such as 'rarely', 'seldom'

gonna.example: The team is <gonna> -> <going to> analyze the data.

nowadays.suggestion: currently, at present, or specify the time

clearly.example: <clearly> -> <The data indicate> that this is the case.

it is obvious that.example: <it is obvious that> -> <The results show that...>

In conclusion.suggestion: use a more formal summarizing phrase

To sum up.suggestion: use a more formal summarizing phrase
